body.p:
Louisville Ky
May 8th 1865
Gov Bramlette
Dear Sir
I have been requested to write you in behalf of one Thos Woodward who was, one day last week, found guilty of man-slaughter and assigned a two year term in the state penitentiary.
In the general I am opposed to pardons, but now and then cases worthy of the exercise of Executive clemency occur. This is one of them.

What Woodward did, was done in Self defense. The Bakers (one of whom he Killed) were bad men and the only wonder is that, they have managed to escape so long. I had a talk with Mr. Dupuy, the Commonwealth's atty, this evening about this case and his remark was that he was not sure the verdict was right. under all the circumstances, I hope you will not hesitate in Extending to this man your official pardon

I am, Governor, most truly
Your Friend
Jo. G. Wilson
